titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: Heard Mr Holland, in the morning from 1. John 4:16—[“]God is love: and he that dwelleth in love, dwelleth in God; and God in him”—and in the afternoon, from Hebrews 4.9—“There remaineth therefore a rest to the People of God”— Mr Holland is not happy in the exterior of eloquence— He has a downcast almost sheepish look in the Pulpit, is awkward in his action—has a harsh grating voice; and little knowledge of its appropriate modulation—but his composition is good—his style animated, and highly oratorical—dealing quite as much as the soberness of religious discourse should do in metaphorical amplification and hyperbole— His morning Sermon was a hymn of glory to love— Meaning thereby benevolence—charity— The afternoon discourse was but a sequel to the same—with a somewhat perplexing enquiry concerning the place of Heaven— The preacher declared his entire belief that the general idea of Christians as to the place of Heaven—in the sky—beyond the Stars was erroneous— He appeared to discredit the resurrection of the body, and perplexed himself a little with the inquiry, what will be the specific character of happiness in the future world— He was quite sure it would be in the exercise of love—benevolence—charity; which brought him again into the track of the morning Sermon— They were both very animated, and excited close and constant attention. I read the second Sermon of the 8th. Volume of Saurin; upon the Empire of Jesus Christ in the Church—in which there is introduced an argument for Toleration— One of those in which he starts strong objections to meet them with weak Solutions— I agreed with Mr E. Price Greenleaf, to suspend for the present our morning walks—to resume them, with divine permission the next autumn— I have found them very agreeable— I read several Letters from Walpole to Mann— One which introduces the name of Washington in 1754—and one or two upon Braddock’s defeat, and his character— Several remarkable Letters concerning Bolingbroke—

Josiah Adams junr. came this morning, and discussed with me the contract, for building a new Farmhouse at Mount Wollaston— He wishes the contract to be made jointly with him and George Veazie. He asked for the plan, which was in possession of Alpheus Spear.— Dr Jacob Richards now of Weymouth but heretofore of Scituate, came and left me part of the papers relating to the claim for the restoration of the Pension of Thomas Church, from the Time when he was struck off the Pension list until his death— He had a Petition signed by Church’s daughters, which he took back to obtain the signature of the husband of one of the daughters, which he will send me, together with the testimony to Church’s poverty— He asked me if it would not be possible to obtain a list of restoration generally of Pensions to all those who have been struck off the list— I promised to make enquiry into the subject, and if I should find just ground for it, to move for the repeal of the Act of Congress, under which many Pensioners were struck off the list— After dinner, Mr Solomon Lincoln, and Mr Charles Lane were here and Mr Lane brought with him a model of the fire grate which Mr Lane claims to have patented He shewed and explained its operation to me—not however so that I could fully understand it— They said they would forward this model to the superintendent of the Patent Office by the Mail to-morrow, and the new specification of the Patent to me. Alpheus Spear was here this Evening— I read to him the draft of a new Lease of the Mount Wollaston farm for five years, which I had prepared, and he took it with him for examination— I engaged to go to the Farm on Wednesday— I planted Apple-seeds Pear-seeds, Plum stones, Tulip tree seeds, and Shagbark walnuts in the Seminary border— A Shagbark walnut and a black walnut both in their drupes at the East end of the Seminary alley, with a Pear core between them, and in the box next to the road.

Henry Hardwick came to me this morning, about that little strip of Saltmarsh land, for which he has been four or five years negotiating— I offered it for him, as the fence now runs, for fifty dollars, which he thought so enormous that I expected to have heard no further from him concerning it— But he now disclosed his purpose— He wishes to have it to the road, so that he may remove the fence, and take in a larger slip— Alpheus Spear had understood his intent before, and had hinted to me the expediency of bounding him by the fence as it now runs— He finally said he would endeavour to purchase another piece of Saltmarsh, and asked if I would buy his short acre locked in with my land— I told him I wood for a reasonable price— Mr Josselyn stopp’d at my front yard fence, and repeated his complaint at having been disappointed in missing the purchase of my Oak timber on the Mount Wollaston farm— He thought Souther, and William Spear had not treated him fairly—and hinted that Spear had selfish views, to obtain a job of work for himself— He predicted also that I should not obtain so much by the sale to Souther, as he would have given me— My Son Charles came out and dined with us and returned this Evening— Mr Herring of New-York, and Mr Cheney the engraver came about the engraving of the Portrait by Stewart of my mother,—for the gallery of American Portraits— Mr Herring wished to have the engraving done immediately, and called on me for a biographical notice of my mother and for notices to be put into the hands of Mr W. L. Stone for a biographical account of my father— I told him I could not prepare them during the Session of Congress, and Mr Cheney seemed quite as little prepared for his work as I was for mine— If he needs my mother’s Portrait during the Winter he will apply for it to my Son Charles— Josiah Adams junr. and George Veazie were here in the Evening and we discussed the contract for building a new House at Mount Wollaston— A new charge of 200 dollars was started for painting the house inside and out, and for window blinds and shutters; and threw the contract, and Alpheus Spear’s Lease all aback— Adams is to see Spear this Night or to-morrow morning.
4. IV. Wednesday

I was engaged, writing, last Evening till 10. O’Clock—my fire had gone out, and I had got insensibly chilled with cold— I went to bed, and was four hours recovering my natural warmth; and two hours more without closing my eyes in sleep— I lost the Night— At four I rose, and after reading a few pages of Hewlett’s prolegomena, wrote till Josiah Adams junr. and Alpheus Spear came; with whom I discussed again the building of the House at Mount Wollaston, and the renewal of Spear’s lease— Adams finally concluded to go to Bangor, for lumber, and went to Boston to embark in a Schooner ready to sail this day— Spear agreed to pay 10 per cent more rent upon 200 dollars additional for painting the house inside and out, for blinds and window shutters— My wife with Louisa C Smith and Mary’s two children, went into Boston; dined at Charles’s and returned, early this Evening— I answered a Letter that I had received from Lieutt. Governor Samuel T. Armstrong—and return a Letter from Dr. Pearce which he had enclosed to me, and which contained the charge referred to the visiting Committee of the Board of Overseers. It is much more comprehensive than I had anticipated— But it will not be in my power to meet again with the Committee.— I sowed two rows of Apple and Pear seeds with plums, Shag-bark walnuts and Tulip-tree seeds in the cleared hazel bush patch— I walked also to the Mount Wollaston farm, where Kirk was transplanting from my garden and Nursery fifteen large English White Oaks— I directed him also to transplant about twenty seedling walnuts, and as many Elms of the third year, and four horse-chesnuts all thinn’d from my Garden— As the time of my departure for Washington approaches the pressure of my occupations become insupportable— Public and Private Affairs equally distressing and nothing consolatory in prospect— I received a long Letter from D. J. Pearce
5. III.30. Thursday.

William Spear came this morning, with Mr Lemuel Humphrey the Surveyor; I went with him to the Railway— There we met, Mr Cary the President of the Railway Company, who was accompanied by his Son, a boy of about 12 years of age— Mr Bryant, the present agent of the company, and Mr Johnson who is to be their agent hereafter— Mr Willard who has lately opened the wigwam lodge, and Mr James Hall, from whom the company purchased much of their land, and who still owns much there, were with us— The Bunker hill Railway passes through three of my lots—the Field, the Joy, and the Savile lots: The company wish to purchase 25 feet from the Railway on the East-side, and 12 feet on the West-side— They have now six-feet wide—and they wish also to purchase a wedge of ground at the termination of their Rail-way.— The distances were measured by Mr Humphrey, through the three lots— At the third the Railway is raised on piles, from 15 to 20 feet high, over a swamp; and the work is so decayed that we could not pass over it— We were kept there upon the Survey till past four O’Clock, and it was near five when I got home— I lent Mr Humphrey the plan taken by Mather Withington in August 1826. of the three lots with the Rail-way passing through them.— Mr. Humphrey promised to return the plan to W. Spear on Saturday Evening, with his own plan of this day’s surveys. Alpheus Spear was here this Evening, pressing for the Execution of his new Lease— I promised to have the two copies of it ready for execution to-morrow Evening— He settled with me also for the parish tax upon the farm for the last four years—making a deduction of about 15 dollars from the tax of the year 1831— This affair has thus been settled without a lawsuit; by a small sacrifice of my right. My Son Charles had engaged to go with us to the Survey on the Railway; but he sent me word last Evening that he should not come out— I finished the observations upon some of Shakespear’s Plays, written at the request of Dr George Parkman, in his copy of Fanny Kemble’s Journal.
6. IV. Friday.

I postponed going to Boston till to-morrow and made out both copies of the Lease of the Mount Wollaston farm to Alpheus Spear for five years from the first of next April— I planted the two remaining open rows of the cleared hazel-bush patch with Apple and Pear Seeds—Shag bark walnuts, plums and Tulip tree seeds— Also the front row of the new bed South and East of the Nursery gate— Two of the rings between the old Pear trees in the garden, and the rings round the seedling Peach trees transplanted into the seminary— Alpheus Spear came this Evening, and we executed the Lease, which was witnessed by Louisa C Smith— I then went to Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s, to enquire concerning the Lease from the Supervisors of the Adams temple and school fund, with the Selectmen of the Town, to the widow Betsey Thayer of a houselot for 100 years—it was executed by the other Supervisors excepting Mr Quincy last Saturday when I was obliged to go to Boston— Mr Greenleaf informed me that it was now in the possession of Mr Lemuel Brackett, who as a Justice of the Peace took the acknowledgment of the Supervisors and Selectmen— I found at Mr Greenleaf’s, Mr and Mrs. Daniel Greenleaf, and Mrs Baxter and her two daughters— Returned home between 8 and 9.

7. IV. Saturday— Lieutt. Governor Armstrong, told me that the Evening before last a very distinguished person of the whig party said to him— Now it is best to be fair and candid with you— I think your whole course this year has been wrong— You ought to have publicly declined to be voted for as Governor— You ought to have presided at the Meeting at Faneuil Hall which nominated Mr Webster as a Candidate for the Presidency, and you ought to have been on the ticket for the House of Representatives from Boston. He said he would tell me next Summer, who it was— I have no doubt it was Abbott Lawrence— He said a man must stand by his party.

I went into Boston this morning, taking with me, Mary’s two children— My first call after stopping a few minutes at Charles’s house, was at the Lieutt. Governor Armstrong’s, and with him I had a conversation of about three hours— First respecting the report of the visiting Committee of the Overseers of Harvard University, to the board— He read me a draft of a Report which he had prepared, and which was satisfactory to me— He had a Letter from President Quincy recommending Jones Very of the Senior Class for the Madam Saltonstall’s prize and West of the same Class for the Madam Alford prize— But what the benefactions are, and why they should be conferred on those two young men was not explained.— I thought these enquiries should be made, and answered before making the Report to the board—and I suggested the expediency of adding some remarks upon the mutilation of books taken out by Students from the university Library, and proposing some remedy for the evil.— It would perhaps be more appropriately the duty of the Committee on the Library— We had next some conversation upon present political prospects— An election warmly contested— He told me he did not think that Edward Everett would be elected Governor by the People— He said he had been excessively urged, to decline; but had thought it unnecessary inasmuch as he had not been asked— He said much more than I have time to record— From his house I went to the Branch Bank, and made preparation for our departure— Then to Dr George Parkman’s but he was not at home— I left the volume of Fanny Kemble’s Journal with my Compliments— I may probably never see him again, as he is going next Spring with his family to Europe. He is an amiable, sensible, unpretending man, and has been one of a very few unvarying and disinterested friends to me— I dined at my Son Charles’s house, and immediately after dinner returned to Quincy, with Mary, her two children and Elizabeth C. Adams whom we took up at Edward Miller’s—
8. IV. Sunday—

Heard Mr Lunt, this morning from Matthew 5.43. [“]Ye have heard that it hath been said, Thou shalt love thy neighbour, and hate thine enemy: 44. But I say unto you, Love your Enemies, bless them that curse you, do good to them that hate you, and pray for them, which despitefully use you, and persecute you”— This was an argumentative Sermon, in reply to the objection that the precept is contrary to the nature of man— Resentment for injuries, it is affirmed is the Law of nature— To require of men that they should love their enemies, is to exact an impossibility— It is to enervate the Soul and to debase the Spirit— To love your enemy is impracticable—and the precept by requiring more than a man can sincerely give, leads to an ostensible obedience, which terminates in outward profession and inward hypocrisy— The reply was very ingenious and forcible— The forgiveness of injuries is the highest glory of the Christian Code of Morals— It is not impracticable— It is exemplified by Millions, every hour of the day— Mr Lunt’s afternoon text was from Revelation 21.4. “And God shall wipe away all tears from their eyes; and there shall be no more death, neither sorrow, nor crying, neither shall there be any more pain; for the former things are passed away”— This was a discourse of a very unusual character— An attempted glance at the condition of the disembodied Soul, beyond the grave— A narrative of human life, to the blessed in heaven, by a Spirit just released from life upon Earth— It was deeply solemn and impressive, and even painfully affecting. The third Sermon of the 8th. Volume of Saurin, upon the difference between the Citizen of Heaven and the Citizen of the world was cold and tame, in comparison, with the awful eloquence of the new-comer to the skies from the imagination of Mr Lunt— It sunk into my heart, with a melancholy sentiment for the remainder of the day— I told Mr Lemuel Brackett that I would call on him to-morrow morning, and asked William Spear to call upon me— Received from him Mr Humphrey’s plan of the Survey made by him at the Railway last Thursday.
9. IV:30. Monday

William Spear was here early this morning, and took my directions respecting the leasing of the house and farm at the foot of Penn’s Hill— The land has for the last five years been leased in parcels— I wish it now to be leased to one person— I desired Spear to give the offer of it first to Harvey Field, at a rent of 350 dollars a year and the payment of all the taxes— If he declines taking it at that rate, then, it is to be offered to Alpheus Spear—who will take it, leaving Totman, the present tenant in the House— I spoke with Mr Spear also, of the land which the Railway company are proposing to purchase of me at the Quarries— I shall not be able to settle this affair before my departure— Asa Colburn who proposes to open a ledge upon my land on the Hill opposite the house, was here, and I executed the agreement with him which was attested by Louisa C. Smith, and Elizabeth C. Adams. There was only one copy of it, but the other is to be made out and delivered to him— I went to Mr Lemuel Brackett’s and executed the Lease of the lot from the Supervisors of the Adams Temple and school fund, and the Selectmen of the Town of Quincy to Mrs Betsey Thayer— Mr Brackett took the acknowledgment, and with Thomas Adams junr. witnessed my signing and sealing— He thence went to Mrs Thayer, to witness with Adams the execution of the Indenture by Mrs Adams and to take her acknowledgment— The signature of Mr Quincy is yet to be taken— I was engaged part of the day before and after dinner in planting Apple and Pear Seeds, Shagbark walnuts ash seeds and acorns; in my Garden and Earthen-Pots— But have now no time to discriminate— I planted a whole row of Greenleaf Apples 60 in number, on the border of the bed where the tall, two year Apple seedling is; with wild plums in the interval between the Apples— Also whole Apples and Pears in the opposite border— 5 whole sound dwarf tree Apples in Box N. 1. and four rows of Apple and Pear Seeds with plums in the same box— This was the day of the annual election for the Legislature and Government of the Commonwealth— I did not attend the town meeting.
10. IV. Tuesday.

This was a day of great anxiety of preparation for our departure for Washington. Elizabeth C. Adams left us and went into Boston— She was in affliction for the death of her Cousin Ann Harrod, of the yellow fever, at New-Orleans, of which she had just been informed— My Son Charles with his wife and daughter came out and dined with us; and returned home after dinner— I had visits from Mr Whitney and Mr Lunt, and afternoon visits from Mr Alexander H. Everett, and Mr Hallett. Everett has been discarded from the whig tickets both of Senator for the County of Suffolk, and of Representative for the City of Boston— The whig Tickets both for Senators and for 72. representatives for the City have prevailed— But in the Counties of Norfolk, Plymouth, Bristol, and Middlesex, the joint tickets of Anti-masons and democrats have prevailed— Everett and Hallett were much encouraged by the general issue of the election, although the whig party retain a majority in both branches of the Legislature; and have also elected their Lieutt. Governor, George Hull. I had no time this day to finish my plantations of Apple and Pear Seeds, plum-stones and walnuts, but left it to be done by John Kirk, who with his wife is to remain here until the 22d. of this Month— I sent for Mr Carr and agree with him that he shall keep my pair of Coach horses through this winter at 1 dollar 25 cents a week for each horses— I settled all the bills that I could get in, and wrote out and executed an agreement with Josiah Adams junr. to build the house and make the repairs at Mount Wollaston upon which I had agreed with Alpheus Spear I was up till past midnight packing for departure.
11. IV. Wednesday.
From Quincy to Boston— Providence— Steamer President Newport— Round Point Judith—back to Newport.
Planted 2 whole Office Apples and 1. Garden button pear in box next the road opposite my chamber window.

At seven this morning Gillet came with his Stage, and took me, with my wife, our daughter Mary Catherine, her two children, Mary Louisa, and Georgiana Frances, John Wilson and his wife Mary Ann, Catherine Goods and Rachel Thomas, to Boston, to the Depot of the Boston and Providence Rail-road— Found my Son Charles waiting there; and took leave of him— We came all together in one division of a Car, and alighted at half past 11. at the wharf in Providence, where the Steamer President, Captainwas ready to depart— It began to rain immediately after we left Quincy; and to storm before we started from Boston— A heavy Southeast gale with driving wind accompanied us till we reached Providence, and we were almost drenched in passing from the Car to the Steamer— We left Boston precisely at nine, and performed that part of our Journey in two hours and a half— At Noon the Steamer loosened from the wharf, the storm still raging, and about 3. P.M came to at Newport— The Storm then had ceased, and the wind came round to West-North-west, clearing the sky to crystal, but blowing still a gale— Our Captain waited till about 9 this Evening, to allow the swell of the Sea off Point Judith to subside, but upon going out the gale was still so heavy that the boat could not stem the waves, and after beating against them, pitching and rolling for two hours with out advancing three miles, the boat became restive to the helm, and it became necessary to return to Newport and lay at the wharf till morning— In the evening before we left the wharf Mr Dutee J. Pearce came on board the boat and spent a couple of hours with me in conversation— He told me that S. S. Southworth was at Providence—had acknowledged to him the receipt of my Letter, and said it would be published in the Bangor Whig.
12. VII. Thursday.
From Newport to New-London—and Long-Island Sound—

At eight O’Clock this morning we parted again from the wharf at Newport, with a clear sky, but a heavy gale, West-North-west, which continued the whole day.— On doubling Point Judith, and until we reached the Eastern end of Fisher’s Island the boat laboured exceedingly, and all my family and most of the other passengers were Sea-sick. Among the multitude, there were of my acquaintance, Mr Nathan Appleton, and his family, two Sons and two daughters, going to New-York, there to embark for Havre, to spend a year or two in France and Italy; chiefly for the health of one of the daughters who has symptoms of pulmonary complaints— Mr Stephen C. Phillips, of Salem, member of the House of Representatives of the United States from theDistrict of Massachusetts; his wife; her Sister, Miss Peale, seven children, and four Servants. They are to pass some time at New-York before the Meeting of Congress— Mr Rezin D. Shepherd, who is going to take up his permanent residence at Baltimore, where his daughter and only child, with her husband Gorham Brooks is settled— Mr George Truman is also of our company— We passed inside of Fisher’s Island, and at 3 in the afternoon went into New-London for a fresh supply of pine-wood fuel— While lying at the wharf, I strolled into the Streets, and was accosted by a man of Falstaff-size, who announced himself to me, as the mate of the Ship Washington when we came from London to New-York in 1817. He said he had been constantly since that time engaged in whaling voyages, and had very lately arrived from the South Sea— At 7. in the Evening we left New-London again, the gale still blowing heavily at West North-west— Five hours our boat was stemming wind and tide; after the change of which there was less of commotion— I was up till near one of the morning reading a fulsome Article in the North-American Review, upon Dr Channing.
13. VI.30. Friday.
From Long-Island Sound to New-York and Philadelphia—

The latter part of the Night, the progress of our bark became easy— At seven this morning we landed at New-York, and the boat that left Providence yesterday at Noon; arrived within an hour after us— We breakfasted at the City-Hotel, where the only acquaintance whom I met was Mr Barnum of the great Hotel at Baltimore;—who told me how he saved his house from the fury of the mob last Summer.— At ten O’Clock we took the Steam-boat for Amboy, where we landed between one and two— Then the Rail-way Car, in which we came to Bordentown at four— Then the Steam-boat for Philadelphia, where at seven we landed upon Chestnut Street wharf; and came and took lodgings for the Night, at Congress-Hall, corner of Chesnut and third Streets.— Here, after tea, Mary left us, taking her daughter Mary Louisa with her, and went to her friend Mrs Clapp’s, having promised to spend a week or ten days with her.— Our fellow travelers from New-York were with very few exceptions different from those with whom we came through the Sound— No old acquaintance, save a man, who as formerly a resident at Haverhill, had known me there; named Plummer— And a resident at New-Bedford named Bartlett— I walked to Mr Nicholas Biddle’s, and found him laid up on a Settee with a lame leg and foot. About three weeks since he met with a fall in the Street, and in the struggle to recover himself snap’d the tendon of the calf of his leg— He is confined for three Months if he ever recovers the used of his leg— But he keeps his Spirits up cheerful— Mrs Biddle and his family are at his seat in the Country— I sat with him, in conversation till past Midnight, and frankly told him of the troubles of my present position, and of the deep anxieties of my prospects for the winter.— While I was with him W. B. Reed came in and spent an hour, much elated with whig victories, and already much of an Anti-mason— Mr Biddle urged me to take the dispute with France in hand— It was one in the morning when I returned to my lodgings.
14. V:30. Saturday—
From Philadelphia to Baltimore and Washington.

At seven O’Clock this morning we embarked in the Steamer Robert Morris, and at ten landed at Newcastle— Then crossed in the Railway Cars, in one hour to French-town— There embarked in the Steamer Constitution, and at four in the afternoon landed at Baltimore— There we were detained till half past five, when we entered one of three Railway Cars and arrived at Washington at eight in the Evening— Mrs Adams the women, and Fanny came all together home in a Hack and I walked from the landing place at the foot of the Capitol Hill— At half past eight I entered the house where I have resided the last six winters— May a blessing rest upon it!— Mr Stephen C Phillips was one of our fellow Passengers from Philadelphia— He had left his family at New-York, and came, with the Mail which leaves that City at four in the afternoon— Arrives after Midnight at Camden opposite to Philadelphia, whence he crossed the river at five this morning— He comes to Washington to engage lodgings for himself and his family for the winter and to bespeak his Seat in the House of Representatives— He intends to go back for New-York on Monday or Tuesday. There were two or three other persons, who recognized me as old acquaintance; but whom I did not remember—

We have thus for the first time accomplished the whole journey of five hundred miles from Boston to Washington City, by Steam Five conveyances by water, and four by land, Two of the Railroads, that from Boston to Providence, and that from Baltimore to Washington, have been opened since I left this City to return home last May— Our detention in the passage of the Sound was equivalent to the addition of 170 miles to our Journey— We have been four days.— But never to remembrance has my mind in travelling, been in so complete a state of stagnation as upon this Journey— I have neither written, read observed nor reflected— What then will be the Winter?
15. VIII. Sunday— Washington.

Four Nights successively with scarcely two hours of Sleep each Night; and incessant travelling with alternation of Railway and Steam-boat, had wearied me so thoroughly that it was 8 this morning when I rose— I attended public worship at St. John’s Church. A stranger read prayers for the 22d. Sunday after Trinity, and preached in the Morning from Hebrews 9.27. “And as it is appointed unto men, once to die, but after this the judgment[”]— Mrs Frye, and her Son Thomas came in immediately after Church, and stayed and dined with us— Dr Huntt also paid us a visit— After dinner I went to the second Presbyterian Church, but met Mr M’Lellan, who informed me that their second Service was at seven in the Evening— I went therefore again to St. John’s and heard the same Stranger, read the Evening prayer, and preach from Mark 8.36—“For what shall it profit a man, if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own Soul? 37. Or what shall a man give in exchange for his Soul?” Both the Sermons were upon the judgment day; and they were deeply solemn and impressive—without enthusiasm, but not without eloquence— After church I went to call upon Mr Phillips at Gadsby’s—but met Mr John Connell who was coming to visit me.— I turned back with him, and saw Mr Phillips at Connell’s chamber. Phillips has engaged the whole of one of Fuller’s Houses for his family, for the winter, and he disengaged himself from dining with me to-morrow as he had promised, as he has concluded to go to morrow at 4. O’Clock in the afternoon, in the railway Cars to Baltimore— On my return home, I found Mr Frye and Mrs W. S. Smith at our house, with Mrs Frye and Thomas— They all went soon away, my wife being very unwell, and obliged to retire to bed— I wrote a Letter to my Son, and journalised for the day.
16. VI:30. Monday

I called this morning at the Office of the Secretary of War, with the Petition of Thomas Vinson, for the increase of his Pension, and the papers in the case of Thomas Church who was a pensioner under the act of March 1818. and was struck off the list under the Act of May 1821— He promised to enquire into both the cases and inform me of the result— I intimated my intention to propose a repeal of the Act of 1821. and said I should probably move a call for a Statement of all the pensioners who had been struck off from the list, because they had some property— I conversed with him also, on the controversy between Ohio and Michigan, and the self-Constitution of the latter into a State; for which he said there was a precedent in the case of the State of Tennessee— He spoke also of the Public Lands, for the sale of which in the present year he said the proceeds paid into the Treasury would amount to ten Millions of dollars— We had also a long conversation upon the state of our dispute with France, which I greatly fear from what he said, that there is little prospect of its being satisfactorily adjusted— He spoke of a declaration to be made by the President in his message that the French Government had demanded an explanation, which never could or would be given— I said Negotiation was the art of avoiding direct issues; and that if such a declaration should be made, I thought settlement would be farther off than ever— I called at the Officers of the National Intelligencer, and ordered the paper to be sent to my house. Then at the Patent-Office, with the papers of Charles Lane of Hingham— Then at the Capitol, where I took my seat in the House— Saw Burch, Overton Carr and Follansbee there— Then at judge Cranch’s— Saw Mrs Cranch, and delivered to her from Mrs. John Geenleaf a packet. Home about 3. O’Clock P.M.—
17— III. and VI:30. Tuesday

I have taken a very severe cold, and awoke this morning about 2. O’Clock— At three I rose—wrote till five, and then went again to bed for an hour and a half— I was occupied upwards of two hours in searching among my papers for the copy of Mr Crawford’s cypher, but without success.— I found however a number of Letters and despatches, belonging to the Department of State—which have been packed up with my papers, since I have been out of office— I took them to the Department of State where I saw first Asbury Dickins the Chief Clerk and afterwards the Secretary Forsyth— I enquired if there was upon the Records of the Department a copy of the Report of Thomas Jefferson of 24. April 1790 to President Washington upon the constructive power of the Senate in the case of Appointments of Ministers to Foreign Countries— I examined the Volume of Reports made by Mr Jefferson to both Houses of Congress, but it was not among them— Mr Forsyth said there was no doubt a copy of it, among Mr Jefferson’s papers in the possession of Thomas Jefferson Randolph his Grandson— Mr Forsyth’s anxiety to procure a copy of Mr Crawford’s cypher is to obtain evidence in support of a Statement that the Emperor Alexander, through General La Fayette did offer to include the claims of the United States against France, with those of the allied Powers; but that Mr Crawford declined assenting to it— Forsyth spoke also of a claim by the Belgian Government for reciprocity of duties, founded upon a questionable allowance by us of the same to the Hollanders— It was left a standing controversy with the Dutch when my administration terminated— Forsyth said the President would mention it in his Message, and that his opinion concurred with mine, in this case— After this visit I spent the rest of the day at home— Walter Hellen was here this afternoon
18. V:15 Wednesday.

I brought up the arrears of my Diary upon these loose Sheets, and examined the remainder of the papers in my blue Chests, numbers 9. 10. 11. 12. 13. 14. and one without number— I did not find however the papers of the Ghent Negotiation, nor Mr Crawford’s cypher. There are multitudes of useless papers which would make a good bonfire, and will never be good for any thing else— I sent the keys of the six numbered chests to Stone the engraver, who cut corresponding numbers upon the keys—and the key of N. 9. opens also the unnumbered chest— Two of the chests are empty; and will serve for packing all my papers since March 1809. I returned Mr Woodbury’s visit by a card, and called upon him, at his office of Secretary of the Treasury— Had a conversation with him upon the alteration proposed of the Laws for the collection of the Revenue— He referred me to the Report on that subject made by him at the last Session of Congress; and to a Bill which then passed the Senate, but not the house— I spoke also of my intention to propose again a rule of the house requiring the Committee of Ways and Means to report the general Appropriation Bills, within thirty days from the beginning of the Session, or the reasons for further delay— He said this might easily be done, as he had made the last annual Report on the Finances, the first week of the Session, and should do so again— I spoke of the unconstitutional provisos inserted into Appropriation-Bills, as of an exceedingly dangerous practice— He spoke of the Patronage-Bill, of the last Session, and of the Boston pamphlet in opposition to it; which he characterised as of great ability— I told him that I was not the author of it, and told him also who was— He said it had given him a new view of the subject, and quite conclusive against the Bill— I called also at the Office of the National Intelligencer and saw Mr Seaton— Evening visit from General Macomb, and Mary, with her daughter Mary-Louisa returned this Evening from Philadelphia— W. C. Greenleaf was here this morning.
19. IV:30. Thursday

I heard both children read this morning— Louisa resumed the reading of the Bible with the first and second Chapters of the Book of Numbers— I began a Letter to Dr George Parkman, intending to write five or ten lines to bid him farewell, and they dilated into four pages which absorbed all the labouring part of the day— I read too some pages of the Moral Class-book, and a chapter of the Natural History of Insects,—and great part of the Poem of Romeus and Juliet, by Arthur Brook, printed in 1562. and from which Shakespear’s whole Tragedy of Romeo and Juliet was taken— All the principal characters of the Play are there—The Montagues, the Capulets, Mercutio, Tybalt, Countie Paris, the Nurse, Friar Lawrence and the Apothecary— There are many beautiful passages in the poem, which is nearly as long as the Tragedy and contains at least 3000 lines— In this Poem Capulet says that Juliet, is not yet sixteen—too young to be a bride—and Romeo is said not to have yet a beard upon his chin— My attention was distracted by this waste of time— I had visitors. Mr Lindsley, who is a Candidate for the Office of Serjeant at Arms to the House of Representatives—Mr Hawley with Mr Wheeler a Clergyman from New-York—Judge Cranch; and after dinner Mr W. S. Smith— Mr and Mrs Frye dined with us— I waited till near three O’Clock to walk out; and then took to the Patent Office a Letter of last July, from the Superintendant of the Office, instead of one which I received from him the day before yesterday— I must call there again to-morrow, and at more seasonable hours— The Attorney General is not here, though soon expected to sign Mr Lane’s Patent, so that there will be no avoidable delay, Mr Hawley told me that the Clergyman who preached for him at St. John’s Church was Mr Dana, settled at Alexandria—
20. IV:30. Friday.

The weather is more like that of July or August, than of November, and the Anthracite Coal fires have brought upon me the catarrhal Cough, which for several winters past has harrassed me, and from which I can never more expect to be free— As the Session of Congress approaches, I feel the duty of preparing, by search for information to act upon measures which may come before them for consideration— The first which I intend myself to bring before them, is a plan for expediting the passage of the general Appropriation Bills— After consulting the Journals of the House of Representatives, for the last two Sessions, I walked to the Capitol, stopping by the way at the patent Office, where I left the drawing for Mr Charles Lane’s patent, to be copied— At the Office of the Clerk of the House, I looked at the Journal of the Senate at their last Session— In the Library I consulted Hatsell’s Precedents, Greys Parliamentary Debates, and the Journals of the House of Commons, for cases of messages from one House to the other to remind them of a Bill before them— I made a few extracts from them. Jefferson’s manual—Section 47. refers to 3. Hatsell 28 and 5. Gray 154— I examined both those passages, and the Journals of the House of Commons to which Hatsell refers— The latest precedent that I found, of a reminding message, was of Feby 1721-2— I had not time to finish my examination and must resume it— My wife went and took tea with her Sister Mrs. W. S. Smith— I joined her there and walked home with her— In the Evening I began to write upon the proposed Resolution for a new Rule of the House to spur the passage of the Appropriation Bills—and immediately the range of argument for the measure expanded before me— New research became necessary, and I was able to write only a few lines, when bedtime came.
21. III— and IV:30 Saturday.

I rose first at three O’Clock; oppressed with the catarrhal cough, and ordered no fires to be made in my chamber and in the dining room; and there were none the whole day— The morning was warm, but afternoon the wind came round to the Northward, cool—continued writing on a proposed rule of the house, and believe there must be two to effect my purpose of reform— Morning visits from Commodore Chauncey and the Secretary of War Cass. Then from Mr Edward Cruft of Boston, with Henry and George Newman; and Dr George Todsen, who returned last Summer from the Colony at Liberia—of which he gives a very unpromising account— I dined with my wife, Mary and her two Children at Mr Frye’s, where we also spent the Evening— Mr Cruft and the two Newman’s paid a short Evening visit there; and while I was from home General Macomb, with Majors Heileman and Dearborn of the Army called and the Majors left Cards— Mr Connell left none— I received a Letter from my Son, and several others troublesome to be answered— One from a person named Samuel A. Goddard, from Birmingham England, sent with a silver medal, struck there by the temperance reformers— One from R Smith, requesting me to act as one of three judges upon the Addresses offered for the premium upon the opening of the New Theatre in this City, which is to be on the 5th. of next Month— One from George Watterston, Secretary of the Washington National Monument Society, enclosed by Light and Horton, Collectors of contributions for the monument in the State of Massachusetts. I must decline to act as a judge upon the Addresses; I take not much satisfaction in the silver medal, and there is something in the circular from the Secretary of the Monument Society not very delicate or modest— Of Light and Horton I know nothing— The Newspaper from Boston, announce the decease of Dr. James Freeman, the ancient Minister of the Episcopal, Unitarian Chapel Church in Boston—
22. IV:30. Sunday

A North-east wind with drizzling rain the whole day contrasted with the Summer weather of Friday and yesterday Morning. I attended public worship this morning at the 2d. Presbyterian Church, where a very young man preached from Luke 19.10. “For the Son of man is come to seek and to save that which was lost.” The auditory was very small. Mr Edward Smith the late Pastor of that Church left them in June last and removed to New-York. In the afternoon I attended at St. John’s Church. Mr Hawley read the Evening service for the 23d. Sunday after Trinity and preached a short Discourse from Mark 10.47—[“]Jesus, thou Son of David, have mercy on me.” The Sermon was not so alarming as the text; and the day was so dark, as it drew towards Sunset that Mr Hawley had some difficulty to read his own Sermon, and faltered frequently— After Church I had a visit from Captain Gardiner, of the army, who has suffered something in his fortunes, for having heretofore had a political regard and friendship for me— He has been for some time stationed with a company at Fort Warburton on the banks of the Potowmack, between this City and Alexandria; but has now received another destination to Point Comfort— My writing upon the necessity for new Rules of the House of Representatives to hasten the passage of Appropriation Bills swells and swells till it absorbs my attention and crimps my time for every thing else— I read in the morning William Sullivan’s moral Class-book, with which I am upon the whole well pleased— In one passage of the Book he gives a large extract from a Sermon of Buckminster in which he points to the 53d. chapter of Isaiah as the conclusive prophecy of Jesus as the Messiah, of all those usually adduced as such in the Old Testament— It was remarkable that the preacher at the Presbyterian Church this morning read that chapter— It is mysterious and oracular, and applies with clear obscurity to the life and character of Jesus—but yet?
23. IV:15. Monday

Rain and Sleet almost the whole of this day— There seems to be an impulse more powerful than my will which engrosses and swallows up my Time in some one object of occupation to the exclusion of all others— The Rule for the House now forms that object, and I can neither get through with my reflections upon it, nor abstract myself from them— Before dinner I walked to M. A. Giusta’s, and asked him to call with the note that I gave him about this time last year which he promised to do— After dinner I had a visit from Mr Fendall, and had much conversation with him respecting Jonathan Russell’s Ghent conspiracy against me—a full account of which I gave him from his private Letter of 24. December 1814. to Mr Monroe to his triplicate Letter in Walsh’s Gazette of May 1822 Among the dark spots in human nature which in the course of my life I have observed the devices of rivals to ruin me have been sorry pictures of the heart of man— They first exhibited themselves at College—but in the short time that I was there, their operation could not be of much effect— But from the day that I quitted the walls of Harvard, H. G. Otis, Theophilus Parsons, Timothy Pickering, James A. Bayard, Henry Clay, Jonathan Russell, William H. Crawford, John C Calhoun, Andrew Jackson, Daniel Webster, and John Davis, W. B. Giles and John Randolph, have used up their faculties in base and dirty tricks to thwart my progress in life and destroy my character— Others have acted as instruments to these and among these Russell was the most contemptible because he was the mere Jackall to Clay— He is also the only one of the list whom I have signally punished— To almost all the rest I have returned good for evil— I have never wronged any one of them, and have even neglected too much even my self defence against them.
24. IV. Tuesday

More and more oppressed for Time. Morning visits from Mr. and Mrs. B. O. Tayloe.— It was near One O’Clock before I could get out of the house— I walked to the Capitol, and found Mr Franklin the Clerk of the last House of Representatives at his Office— I spoke to him of the Stationary furnished to the members of the House, and told him I hoped it would be better than it was at the last Session— I went in to the Library, and looked over the Volumes of Hatsell’s Precedents of the House of Commons— Wishing to examine them more particularly I bespoke them to be sent to me, promising to return them at the Meeting of Congress— I glanced also at a volume of La Fontaine’s Fables—a Volume of Thornton’s Plautus and Dryden’s Amphitryon, monstrously coarse and vulgar— I find much in Hatsell upon tacking, upon which as upon other matter in his book, I would reflect— There is much altogether irrelevant here— Returning home, I met near my door Mr Thomas Munroe, who had a Letter from Mr Maywood, and who urged me warmly to withdraw my refusal to act as one of the judges, with Mr Cass and Mr Virgil Maxcy, on the Addresses for the opening of the Theatre— I persisted, and told him I had particular reasons for declining— Mrs Wolfenden, tenant of my house on Pennsylvania avenue, came to ask for more repairs on the house, which I rather pettishly declined— I gave her carte blanche for repairs last Spring; which have absorbed almost the whole rent to this time and she wants more— Giusta was here— I took away my note to him of 29. Octr. 1834— I gave him a new one payable in a year with interest at 5 per cent— To be repaid next Spring if he should want it. Evening visit from Mr Connell, who promised to procure for me the pamphlet of Mr Barnes the presbyterian Clergyman for which he has been suspended from preaching by the Synod—
25. IV: Wednesday.

Mary was so unwell, with a severe head-ache that she took to her bed. Dr Huntt was sent for, and thinks it only a bilious remnant of Sea-sickness at the passage through Long-Island Sound— I called upon Mr Thomas B. Johnson at his house— Mrs Frye was with him but soon went away— Mrs Hellen with her daughter Adele afterwards came in and I left them there— I proposed to Mr Johnson to pay him principal and interest the portion of the debt from the Columbia College standing in my name which belongs to him; to which he assented, and requested me to pay it to Mr Frye— I then called at the Pension Office of the War Department, and enquired of J. L. Edwards the Commissioner of Pensions for the Schedule of property of Thomas Church upon which his name was struck from the Pension List in 1820. Mr Edwards promised me a copy of this Schedule which he afterwards sent me— After I returned home, Mr Frye came in and had some conversation with me concerning my private Affairs here; and particularly concerning Speakman the Miller and his post mortem claims— I read this Evening an Article in the last American Quarterly Review upon the question of our present dispute with France— And some pages of the small natural History of Insects of the Harper Edition— I had read also an Ambidexter article in the Review upon A Memoir upon the Life with extracts from the Speeches of Tristam Burges— Huntt told me that the Old Man, meaning President Jackson said to him this morning that the Packet which should have sailed from Havre on the 24th. of October must bring either Barton the Charge d’Affaires or the money— Surely not the money— He spoke also of the phrenological survey of the head of Levi Woodbury—as a Vicar of Bray—
26. IV. Thursday.

Harrassed excessively with my own reflections, upon the proposed new Rule for the Transaction of business in the House upon which I grow disheartened as I proceed—and consider what I ought to say, but what it will probably be of no avail if I do say it— My mind is oppressed beyond what it ever was before, between a sense of public duty to take a bold and indipendent stand; and the almost certainty of being overpowered and broken down in the operation— Mr Connell called upon me to speak of a claim before Congress in behalf of the legal Representatives (children) of Robert Fulton. There have already been favourable Reports of select Committees of the House of Representatives upon it— Connell is now acting as an Agent for the claimants and asked if it would not be advisable to send it to the Committee of Claims if Whittlesey of Ohio should be their chairman, as he will I thought it would— He asked me to introduce him to Whittlesey which I readily promised to do— I walked to the Capitol, and took Seats, for D. J. Pearce, William Sprague, the two members from Rhode-Island, and for Nathaniel B. Borden the new member from Bristol District, Massachusetts, as I had been requested by a Letter, received yesterday from Pearce I went into the Clerk’s Office and enquired of Burch whether he had ever known of a Message from one House of Congress to the other, reminding, of a Bill, before that from the Senate of the close of the last Session— He said he could speak positively as to the last thirty years—there had been no such message He promised to enquire of Mr Lowrie whether he had ever known of such a procedure in the Senate— After dinner my wife went and spent an hour with her Sister Smith. I went after her and walked with her home— I had called on Mr Gales, to thank him for Boston Newspapers he had sent me
27. III:30. Friday.

Snow all the morning; and it fell in sufficient quantity to cover the ground; but before night had in part disappeared— My Speculation for a new rule of the House drags along— So that I fear I shall have no time left for any thing else— I received Letters from my Son Charles and from Alexander H. Everett— I answered a Letter from Joshua Smith of Hanson, Massachusetts, last year and the year before a member of the Legislature; but not so now—and I answer D. J. Pearce’s Letter informing him of the Seats I had taken for him and his colleague Sprague, and for my colleague N. B. Borden in the house. In the Evening I returned the visit of General Macomb; and found only him and Mrs Macomb at home— He persuaded me to play a game of Chess with him, and easily beat me— He gave me the Globe of this day containing a Letter from R. P. Letcher, styled H. Clay’s right bower—remarkable— Written in the House of Representatives on the 7th. of February last immediately after my War Speech as it was called—the Letter is addressed to a member of the Kentucky Legislature named Breck— Letcher confidently prophesies war before a very few Months—reminds Breck that he had told him so before— Says Jackson will have a War, and that Johnny Q. will go with him— Then comments upon my strange Speech— Says Judge White is running for the Presidency, head and tail up— That if he would withdraw his wife would not let him— Says that if there is a War, the whole South to a man will call for Clay to run for the Presidency— That it would be well for the Legislature of Kentucky, to shew some strong mark of confidence in Mr Clay—but asks what can you do, when your own friends are against you— This Letter accounts for Clay’s exasperation at my Speech— It blew up his hopes from the South, in the chance of a War.
28. IV. Saturday

Morning visit from Mr Lawrence, Member of the House of Representatives from Boston, who arrived here last Evening; having come to take his seat in the Hall, and to engage lodgings for his family, which he has done at Gadsby’s— I had a long conversation with him upon general politics, without touching upon any points of collision— I mentioned to him my intention to offer a Resolution for a new rule of the House, and for the restoration of the revolutionary Pensioners of 1818. struck off the list by the act of 1820. and not restored; both of which he approved— And it suggested to me the expediency of proposing the first as far as possible without moving hostilities— But how to do this?— Mr Lawrence returns to Baltimore this Evening— I went to the War Department, but met the Secretary Mr Cass at the gate going to the President’s— I told him I wished a list of the Pensioners struck off the list and not restored might be made out to be ready for a call— He said he believed Mr Edwards the Commissioner had told him there was such a list— I had the papers of Church’s children with me to leave with Mr Cass, but must call on him again next week— I returned Commodore Chauncey’s visit but he was gone to Philadelphia. Saw Seaton at the National Intelligencer Office, and took some Boston Newspapers— Went to the Capitol and found upwards of forty seats taken in the Hall of the House of Representatives— Half hour in the Library— Met George Chambers of Pennsylvania and Samuel F. Vinton of Ohio— Then John B. Forester and Cave Johnson of Tennessee with their wives—and I saw James K. Polk at the door of Brown’s Hotel— In the Evening I read about 20 pages of the Dissertation K. upon the Congress of Nations and became torpid so that I could read no more— I wrote a general Letter of Introduction for Dr W B. Sprague of Albany and enclosed it as he had requested to Charles Butler New York
29. VI. Sunday.

In the Night the wind came round to the North-west, it blew a gale, and this day was clear and severely cold. At the second Presbyterian Church this morning Mr Gurley preached from 2. Corinthians 5.15. “And that he died for all, that they which live should not henceforth live unto themselves, but unto him, which died for them and rose again”—strictly calvinistic—too tough for my digestion— But Mr Hand sent a note to Mr Gurley to invite him to preach again this day— He asked at what hour, for he was engaged this afternoon— Mr Hand said seven in the Evening upon which he gave notice that there would be public worship again there at that hour— Mrs Frye and her Son Thomas were here after the morning service— After dinner at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read prayers for the first Sunday in Advent, and preached from Hosea 10.12 [“]Sow to yourselves in righteousness, reap in mercy; break up your fallow ground: for it is time to seek the Lord, till he come and rain righteousness upon you.” An excellent text, for a feeble commentary, but it was intensely cold— Mr Hawley had in the morning instead of a Sermon read a long pastoral Letter from Bishop White— I finished the sketch of an Essay upon a proposed new Rule for the House of Representatives upon which I have been ten days engaged, and with which I am so dissatisfied, that I shall probably make no use of it whatever.— I received a Letter from S. S. Southworth, dated Providence 10. Novr where he said he was called by domestic afflictions— That he was on his way to Washington— That he had just received my Letter, which would be published in the Bangor Whig and Courier— That he has seen Mr Burges, and is sorry to say that his bitterness towards me, is not often suppressed— Southworth is an author to be let—
30. IV:30. Monday

I had begun three days since a Letter to my Son Charles, and had not found time to answer it till this day; and it took me the day; excepting an hour and a half that I wasted in reading my discourse on a new Rule for the House— Mr John B. Dade of Culpeper County Virginia, brought me a Letter of recommendation from John S. Barbour, formerly member of the House from that District. Mr Dade is a candidate for the Office of Assistant Door-keeper to the House, in the place of W. S. Hunter whom he wishes to supersede. He told me that Mr John Taliaferro who comes instead of Chinn, was his friend; and that John M. Patton was his nephew— He said J. S. Barbour would be glad to run against Patton, and he thought would do so for the next Congress— I went out so late that I could not extend my walk so far as the Capitol— Met Mr Gales—at the Intelligencer Office saw Seaton and P. R. Fendall— Walter Hellen was here this afternoon— I read in W. Sullivan’s Moral Class Book this morning, that there is no reason why a man should not put another man to death civilly— I read also that no well disciplined moral being can have a really disagreeable voice— Sullivan’s father once told me that his Son William was too polite.— And he has a very soft soothing voice— He further says that a penitent pirate may be happy that he is going to be hanged— The Moral Class-book is much admired.

Day— I usually rise about four O’Clock or soon after— Read a Chapter or two in the Moral Class Book— Write one or two hours— Hear Mary-Louisa read two Chapters in the Bible; and Fanny read half a page from some child’s book— Breakfast Read Newspapers two hours.— Walk an hour and a half or two hours Dine between three and four; and attend the tea-table about 7. Journalize about an hour when I can, and read or write myself asleep till bed-time between 9 and 10 at Night.
